jenkins_jobs/modules/triggers.py.message: This is not necessary when using the mapping below.

Why's the default an empty string? but the value above says 'True'. Is this a boolean setting?

If so we should set :arg bool no-squash: and set the default to be true or false depending on what the plugin's normal default configuration is.
convert_mapping_to_xml supports booleans so instead of a blank string set this to true|false depending on which is the plugin's usual default configuration.
Ah in Python it's False with a capital F.  That should fix the Zuul error.
Seems like this isn't resulting in default XML being outputted, I'm a little rusty with the mapping code, but seems like that's not the intended behaviour? Or am I missing something?
the gating CI job for the latest version makes me thing that once the keyval (here no-squash/noSquash) is in 'mapping' here then it has to be part of 'minimal' (aka 002) xml

That would make sense, was assuming this was passing already and was surprised not to see that test case appear in the output.

But I see you've switched behaviour with a newer change, do you really want to not emit the <noSquash> tag when this is left at the default?

So I prefer this code would be part of the mapping as it significanlly cuts down on the amount of code to maintain.

convert_mapping_to_xml actually has 2 modes of operation that affect how the "None" default value triggers the output XML.

fail_required=True, in this mode any option with a default value of "None" will fail JJB and print an error to the user notifying them that this value is required for the operation of this module.

fail_required=False, in this mode any option with the default value of "None" will skip processing XML for thus not generating any XML at all for said option.

Considering the mapping below does not have any None default values you could flip the switch to fail_required=False and then have noSquash XML be skipped in it's code generation.

Typically though for switches that are just a simple true|false value I'd prefer that it just set the default to whatever the plugin defaults to when you configure that plugin via Jenkins Web UI. This makes it extremely clear what the default setting is if you don't set it, rather than letting the user guess as to which the default setting is (or in the case the plugin authors decide to flip flop on what the default value is).

doc/source/developer/specs/tenant-scoped.message: I wonder if we should support skew at all. What is the intended use of this? If clocks are out of sync because of broken clock sync the skew won't be constant.

The JWT RFC says implementations *may* account for clock skew: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519#section-4.1.4

My personal opinion is that it's better to fix clock sync rather than set the leeway here, but we should allow people to do it if they have no other way to account for time discrepancies.

Should lines 1-25 above be in playbooks/ceph-pg.yaml and not in this role?

Lines 1-25 ensure Ansible is using hash_behaviour=merge instead of the default hash_behaviour=replace. This role works with either option. However playbooks/ceph-pg.yaml is written under the assumption that the user will pass their variables the same way they are passed in THT [2] which supports merging. Otherwise parameter_defaults[KEY] may not return anything.

My intention is for playbooks/ceph-pg.yaml to be used before deployment. In theory though, assuming all of the variables could be passed correctly, this role could be used during deployment as an in-flight validation. 

Requiring a change the default behaviour of hashes in a larger ansible execution makes this role is less useful in the rest of TripleO.


[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/config.html#default-hash-behaviour

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694674/6/deploy-guide/source/features/ceph_config.rst@667

Then again, parameter_defaults[KEY], is not something we expose directly to Ansible and since this role uses that a lot, it's not as portable anyway. What we could argue as portable is ceph_pools_pg_protection Ansible module.
might be better to ensure this here, at the lowest level.
Done
I am not sure this is still needed though?

I believe that it is very much needed.

This validation is written for users before they deploy to
know how Ceph will handle their inputs. They deploy like
this and paramter_defaults will be additive.

 openstack overcloud deploy -e foo.yaml -e bar.yaml ...

The idea is to use this validation the same way:

 this_validation -e foo.yaml -e bar.yaml ...

If we use the default, ANSIBLE_HASH_BEHAVIOUR=replace, then
everything in foo.yaml will be completely ignored. If the
contents of the file were like this:

foo.yaml:
  parameter_defaults:
    baz: qux

bar.yaml:
  parameter_defaults:
    quux: quuuux

then, the baz variable won't make it to the Ansible validation
while it would make it to the TripleO deployment of Ceph. Such
a result would be misleading.

We want the user to configure their Ansible so that they
parameter_defaults has the vars from both files and if they
don't have it configured that way, then we need to warn them
that they'd be deceiving themselves. Thus, this validation is
much safer if we insist on this check instead of just relying
on the proposed documentation [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694674/6/deploy-guide/source/features/ceph_config.rst@667

Subnets are one of the 3 fundamental abstractions (along with networks and ports) of Neutron. Everything else is considered an extension and for the purposes of DB models, we try to keep their added attributes out of this models_v2.py. The perfect example in this case is the dns_domain attribute for networks: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/92c8065fb722eb80ced7d6829bdbddf82909d431/neutron/db/models/dns.py#L22-L38. Please implement this new attribute in a similar way. This will also keep us consistent with the way the external DNS integration extensions have been implemented over time. As you see in the rest of my comments, this consistency is the major theme of my review

neutron/db/subnet_dns_publish_fixed_ip_m.message: The entire reason of this mixin is to extend the subnet response dictionary. Please note that the external DNS integration extensions are implemented as ML2 extensions drivers (https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/92c8065fb722eb80ced7d6829bdbddf82909d431/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/dns_integration.py#L38), which are handled by the ML2 extensions manager. This manager will attempt to call an extend_subnet_dict method in each loaded ml2 extension driver https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/92c8065fb722eb80ced7d6829bdbddf82909d431/neutron/plugins/ml2/managers.py#L1166. So extending the subnet dictionary should be implemented with a extend_subnet_dict method. The perfect example to follow for this is the way the dns_domain for ports is handled: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/92c8065fb722eb80ced7d6829bdbddf82909d431/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/dns_integration.py#L395-L403

neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py.message:
As I've mentioned in my other comments, the external DNS integration extensions have been implemented ad ML2 plugin extension drivers. One of the big reasons that this type of drivers were created was to avoid ML2Plugin mixins, like the one you are adding here. To properly load an ML2 plugin extension driver you need the following:

1) Declare an entry point for your new driver, similar to what was done here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/457101/13/setup.cfg@109

2) Once you have that in place, the deployer will have to configure the extension similar to what we describe in point 2 here: https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-dns-int.html#the-networking-service-internal-dns-resolution

If we implement your new extension properly as a ML2 extension driver, this is not needed. The ML2 extensions manager adds you extension to this list if it is configured: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/92c8065fb722eb80ced7d6829bdbddf82909d431/neutron/plugins/ml2/managers.py#L1096-L1106. That is why you wrote https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662409/20/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/subnet_dns_publish_fixed_ip.py@28, which is called from here: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/710d129ca94df443d3b21c546c15e5b4ece23761/neutron_lib/plugins/ml2/api.py#L1110-L1117, which in turn is called from L222 below
See my comment to L212. We don't need this

releasenotes/notes/subnet-dns-publish-fi.message:
Hmm, to me, "to subnets" is the generic form, like "to any subnet" or "to all subnets", while "to the subnets" would only make sense when talking about a specific set of subnets.

But I'm no native speaker, so I may be wrong.

The form "to the subnets" definitely means specific subnets, a subset of all subnets.  The form "to subnets" is somewhat ambiguous, and could mean either "to all instantiated subnets" or "to the class/object that defines what a subnet is".  For maximum clarity I would avoid ambiguity and say "to the definition of the subnet resource".
This is a good idea, amended both locations accordingly.

specs/keystone/pike/api-implemetation-re.message: We also have a /v3/policies API. Adding this will make it confusing as to what is used for what. https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#policies
This isn't the standard format of the json we return in our other APIs. The python-keystoneclient will want you to have this inside of a dictionary key, like: { "policies": { }}
This has a security impact since anyone with an admin token can now download the entire policy file. This should be noted in this section.

This statement makes it seem like Patrole is the thing evaluating and enforcing policy, is that correct? Has this been implemented in any of the other services yet? We have tooling available in oslo.policy to generate sample and hybrid policy files based on overrides, which sounds like it might solve this use case (but I need to understand how Patrole is using policy first).

We try to keep policy away from users of the system since it's an operator thing.

Lance,
I have been working on Patrole since long, here is how it uses policy (Forgot mention that) - 
https://github.com/openstack/patrole/blob/master/patrole_tempest_plugin/rbac_policy_parser.py#L101

In this way, If Patrole node is a remote node (other than controller) it will always check/assume for policy.json file on remote machine. Because oslo_policy is not available to remote. 
In this way Spec proposal comes.

Lance,
OpenStack Patrole is a Tempest plugin to check if policies are correctly enforced or not.
It does not enforce policies instead it check if they are correctly enforced. For more details you can check - https://github.com/openstack/patrole
Please find answers for your questions here -
a. We have registered this blueprint in each component and started with Keystone. So Keystone is the first component we have started with spec and implementation.
b. Yes you are right that overriding tooling is available but it can be done from the OpenStack node (Controller node)only. As being a tempest plugin it must have a capability to evaluate polices (in code or file) from a non OpenStack remote machine node. 
Solution for this can be to copy-paste policy files from openstack controller node to non OpenStack node remote node. This is very odd. So best solution seems to provide an admin restricted policy rule download API.

For any other queries, feel free to ask.

cinderlib/cinderlib.py.message: This concerns me a little. Have we approached the oslo team to see if we can get what we need in a public way without resorting to private calls and variables?

No I haven't approached them because most of what we have to do here related to the configuration is because oslo.config was never meant to be used like this (it's for projects, not libraries which is how we are using Cinder code here).  But I can talk with them as they may have a cleaner solution.

This is a good point.  The oslo.config types have a _formatter function defined on them that's used to generate the default and sample default values when the config generator is used, so if that were exposed, it should be possible to use the defined formatters instead of doing opt->str conversion ourselves.

`_formatter` is still a non-public function, and doesn't seem to give us exactly what we want.

I don't know if this is a bug, an inconsistency, or what, but MultiStrOpt is a MultiOpt where each element is a MultiString instead of just a String type, so if we call opt.type._formatter for the individual elements we get the wrong data, because it treats the string as an iterable and each letter a if it were a string.

It works as expected if we pass to opt.type._formatter the whole array, but if we do that with a MultiOpt of Dicts, then it will raise an error because it gets a list and it expects a dict.

It also doesn't handle a DictOpt with bounds.

In my local repo I have changed the code and tests using the `_formatter` and taking into account the MultiStrOpt issue (but not the DictOpt with bounds) and it does require considerable fewer LOC.

If you prefer I can submit that one, since we don't have any DictOpt with bounds and I don't anticipate us ever having one.

Thanks Jeffrey, you raise some interesting points. I have proposed something not too dissimilar. I have a prototype where the roles are invoked against the cells from site.yml. By overriding group variables, the roles can run with minimal changes (so far I tested HAProxy, MariaDB and RabbitMQ). What do you think?

We need to consider how we'll execute playbooks against these hosts.

The current cells-rabbitmq patch uses a top-level cells-rabbitmq group that the play is targeted against. All cells rabbitmq hosts are added to this group:

[cells-rabbitmq:children]
cell1-rabbitmq
cell2-rabbitmq

[cell1-rabbitmq]
cell1-rmq1
cell1-rmq2
cell1-rmq3

[cell2-rabbitmq]
cell2-rmq1
cell2-rmq2
cell2-rmq3

Then the play does something like this:

- hosts: cells-rabbitmq
  tasks:
    - include_role: rabbitmq
      with_items: cells
      vars:
        rabbitmq_var: "{{ item.rabbitmq.var }}"

The downside of this approach is that RabbitMQ cluster creation is serialised for each cell, and that every cell iteration will have all hosts in cells-rabbitmq, with many just skipped. The upside is that it's conceptually quite simple, as only one cluster is deployed at a time, and you could deploy multiple rabbitmq services per host, if you desire.

Agreed - I have updated the spec to use a different approach where roles can be applied to cells directly from site.yml. This avoids the looping approach. Can we offer a way to include cell configuration without putting files in group_vars? I feel like we shouldn't be encouraging people to (essentially) edit the kolla-ansible source. With my deployer hat on, I certainly don't want to :)

You can define group_vars and host_vars next to playbooks and your inventory. See https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/user_guide/playbooks_variables.html#variable-precedence-where-should-i-put-a-variable.

Slightly annoyingly, playbook group_vars have higher precedence than inventory group_vars.

Agreed that we shouldn't encourage anyone to modify the source, but we could encourage them to keep group_vars next to their inventory. The layout is as follows:

inventory/
  group_vars/
  host_vars/
  hosts

You can reference the inventory as -i inventory or -i hosts.

To add an inventory for each cell, we could do something like this:

inventory/
  group_vars/
  host_vars/
  cell0
  cell1

Then, -i inventory would include all cells, whereas -i cell0 would include only hosts in cell0.

I think that it would be a smaller change to implement that approach (group_vars next to inventory). With the group vars in the inventory file, more variables need to be abstracted to override them due to the lower precedence of inventory group vars. I will create a summary of the various options.

Maybe we should add support for one or two specific scenarios.
 
Rough goals:

* nice if we can add usually add extra compute nodes without resizing the API layer control plane (assuming a mix of pets and cattle)
* ideally scale out API control plane as load increases on the API
* it would be good to make efficient use of all three API control plane nodes

Nova specifics:
* cells lightweight enough to not mix hardware types inside a cell (useful logical container)
* loss of one cell DB (failover, etc) doesn't affect general API availability

Target configuration:
* Three (+n) API controllers
** as API load increases, add controllers
** spread workers out between the nodes
** remove data intensive stuff like Ceph RADOS, Glance.
* Two (+m) Compute controllers
** as you add more compute nodes, add controllers
** glance (with cache), nova cell DBs, cell rabbits, etc
* Separate monitoring
** if monitoring traffic increases, don't kill API
** thinking of log bursts, additional computes
** future may have per compute moninting

To make the above work we could do something like:
* map services to a service group, dedicated or shared
* deploy multiple service groups, each group does:
** deploys mariadb cluster, rabbit cluster, haproxy
** have option of non haproxy, single rabbit with a master-slave DB setup

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Have you verified this works as expected in IPv6?

Tracing back through the history of this particular patch, I get the following long-lost commit message for the change that introduced it, back as a patch to dhcp 4.2.5 almost 4 years ago:

dhcp: only set hostname based on ipv6 lease if not already set

The code that was added to set the hostname based on the incoming DHCP lease
was doing so unconditionally.  This means that hostname would be set to the
last response which could be either mgmt or infra depending on timing.  The end
result is that sometimes the hostname was compute-0 and other times it was
compute-0-infra.  When it resolves to compute-0-infra the compute_config script
fails to find manifests that are named with the board's IPv6 address.

This implements checks similar to those used for IPv4 DHCP and only sets the
hostname if it is not already set.  Since the mgmt interface is always the
first to acquire a lease (i.e., it will request a lease before manifests are
run and therefore before infra exists) the default hostname of the board will
always be set to compute-0 and there will be no opportunity for the -infra name
to be used.

`Task: 28333`
